thread.title: Family of OSU junior who killed himself sues hospital for $2.25 million for not stopping suicide
thread.title_full: Family of OSU junior who killed himself sues hospital for $2.25 million for not stopping suicide | OregonLive.com

author: Aimee Green | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Family of OSU junior who killed himself sues hospital for $2.25 million for not stopping suicide
text:
The family of a 20-year-old Oregon State University student who committed suicide in his fraternity's parking lot has filed a $2.25 million lawsuit against a Corvallis hospital, claiming it failed to get him the help he needed the day before he died.
Friends of Matthew Neyland Keefe brought him to the emergency room at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center on Oct. 6, 2012, about 11:15 p.m. after discovering him unresponsive from consuming sleeping pills and alcohol, according to a lawsuit filed Tuesday. Keefe was "distraught over a relationship with a girl," the suit states.
The hospital discharged him the next day -- Oct. 7, 2012 -- about 1:30 p.m., according to the suit. Less than 28 hours later, the college junior was dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to his chest in the parking lot of his fraternity, Pi Kappa Phi.
The lawsuit faults Corvallis' Good Samaritan hospital, alleging that doctors failed to have Keefe evaluated by a psychiatrist or mental health professional. The suit also alleges that doctors failed to collect a full mental health history from him to gain an understanding of his risk for suicide.
A hospital spokesperson didn't return requests for comment for this story.
The suit states that Keefe is survived by his mother, Stephanie Schmitter, and his stepfather, Jeffrey Schmitter.
It seeks $1.5 million for his family's loss of society and companionship and $750,000 for future lost income that Keefe could have generated.
Keefe's obituary says he was a junior who was studying fermentation science and had a passion for beer brewing.
The lawsuit was filed in Benton County Circuit Court by Portland attorney David K. Miller.
Read the lawsuit here .
-- Aimee Green
agreen@oregonian.com
